text: Flanked by Democratic lawmakers and anti-death penalty advocates, @GavinNewsom announces his exec order to impose moratorium on executions in CA.

text: “Defying voters” is a phrase we’re likely to hear a lot in coming days and weeks. The 2016 ballot fight — no on repeal, yes to expedite — is one Newsom may need to address head on.

text: And that’s a very good point. It should have been widely shared with those who routinely cover this administration. (I should have noted my similar experience at being shut out of embargoed news.)
author: johnmyers

text: Yes, I think there needs to be explicit agreement to an embargo. I also don’t think it should be used all the time. But I disagree that it’s not workable. Embargoes are honored all the time, we just don’t discuss.
author: johnmyers

text: Also, CA media politics Twitter is full of buzz tonight about the broken embargo on the death penalty news. (Note: not us.) With most of my career at small outlets, can attest that an embargo levels playing field for little guys. But when it’s broken, it’s broken.
author: johnmyers

text: Some valuable context in Phil’s thread.
author: johnmyers

text: The second father-son story of a governor and the death penalty. The late Gov. Pat Brown (briefly) switched positions on the 1960 execution of Caryl Chessman when his Jesuit seminarian son, Jerry, urged him to block the action.
author: johnmyers

text: Tomorrow’s news tonight: @GavinNewsom will order a moratorium on the death penalty, raising questions about race and class in sentences of execution.
author: johnmyers

text: Thanks to the crack @TheStateHornet staff for having me over. So great to hang out with the next generation of journalism superstars.

text:
I’m not sure why #Prop7 backers didn’t focus on the easier option — after all, their not-quite-proven arguments (deaths rise when time changes) would also end via all-year ST, right?

Anyway, food for thought. In the meantime, my kids will complain abt early bedtime tonight. -30-
author: johnmyers

text:
So... if you’re the impassioned #CALeg members hoping to avoid Congress sitting on your no-time-change effort, what do you do?

Easy: pass CA law imposing year-round *standard* time. 1966 federal law gives that option ( AZ & HI.) Presto: No more changing the ... /5
author: johnmyers

text: Assuming that effort — plus @GavinNewsom’s embrace of the state law  — happens, then the really long odds of being approved by Congress. Yes, FL is asking for same permission. But trying to convince Washington that this is (1) a priority and (2) no big deal seems super tough /4
author: johnmyers

text: With that hurdle gone, those who want year-round DST in CA now have two challenges. First, get 2/3 vote in each #CALeg house to ratify the plan. That will require substantial agreement, even as a key Dem in the state Senate wrote the ballot argument against #Prop7. /3
author: johnmyers

text: For starters, it’s worth remembering that #Prop7 simply removed the state law impediment to a single, year-round measurement of time in CA. (And note I’m not limiting it to DST.) That barrier was imposed by voters in 1949. /2
author: johnmyers

text: Social media is chock full of folks on this daylight saving day lamenting the time change. And pols who pushed #Prop7 on last year’s ballot keep saying, “This could be the last time you’ll change those clocks!” — messaging aided by some lazy journalism and highly misleading. /1
author: johnmyers

text: This morning’s politics column: California Republicans will get an equal voice with Dems in the state’s 2020 redistricting.

text: I appreciate your points, but it’s hard to dismiss the issue simply by saying external forces are to blame.  Also, last time I checked the true “employer” was the CA taxpayer. If the taxpayer’s representatives strike costly deals, it seems reasonable for us to say so.

text: Worth noting the high court skipped weighing in on the larger issues of the "CA Rule" and its long-term protection of benefits promised to public employees. So the larger pension debate likely to rage on...

text: I’m starting to believe the Trump-Newsom dynamic will be one of the year’s most intriguing storylines. Both men are likely to use the other as a constant foil to their base supporters. Both thrive on social media. Both will see if they can get under the other guy’s skin.
author: johnmyers

text: The fatal shooting by Sacramento police of Stephon Clark last year will make news this afternoon: will the DA file charges? As ⁦@chabriaa⁩ wrote recently, the city’s African American community is looking instead for #CALeg action.

text: Patterson’s ascension as #CAGOP chair is a victory for the institutional power of the party, what’s left of it. (Both major parties have rules that tend to give the existing power structure a leg up.) Now the big Q: What can she do to move the party forward?
author: johnmyers

text: Today’s column: 2,576 bills introduced by last week’s deadline in the California Legislature. Many uncooked, many quietly written by lobbyists. Does the process need changes?
author: johnmyers

text: Depends on whether you’re a reporter in search of a story. In which I remember several where the answer was... yes.

text: One wonders, then, why he hasn’t filed his own lawsuits. Bears repeating: voting mistakes, even cases of fraud, aren’t non-existent in CA. But widespread nefarious efforts are a baseless assertion.

text: @GavinNewsom departs CA for the National Governors Assn. meetings in DC. That means, too, the first chance for @EleniForCA to serve as acting governor.

text: Received the smallest percentage of the vote of any Republican in modern history (or longer). Yes, some will say he was walloped by a bad brand... but the Trump endorsement not likely to soon be forgotten.

text: It doesn't look to me that the six-part installment leaves anything out. Am I missing something?
author: johnmyers

text: Nothing's more awkward than noting the 16-year old was too young to vote for her. And yet, DiFi later likes the young woman's idea of being her intern. Gray areas -- i.e., real life -- hard to see in a world of social media snippets. Differing opinions of how DiFi handled things.
author: johnmyers

text: I'm grateful to those who have posted the entire video (6 parts, I think). Context! From my journalist's vantage point, it offers a glimpse at a senator who certainly listens to the points made but also is frustrated at times, making for some awkward interactions.
author: johnmyers

text: Sure, a fair point. But the senator's irritation is what's making this video go viral. Certainly she's been in more frustrating situations than this one, right?
author: johnmyers

text: Yeah, I think that's why the video has gotten traction with some news outlets. It does not seem to be her best moment.
author: johnmyers

text: And I certainly appreciate that. It's one of the most talked about videos on my Twitter feed tonight, but there are varying takes on it out there from people who have always struck me as pretty level-headed.
author: johnmyers

text: Sure, certainly a reasonable read of the video. But like with so many viral moments, I want to know what happened *before* the clip. How did the dialogue begin, did she have a clash with adults before kids began speaking, etc. I always want unfiltered version of things like this.
author: johnmyers

text: Video of DiFi talking (debating?) kids & young adults over Green New Deal is sparking very different reactions. Hard to deny they wanted to pin her down and she was unhappy with their approach. But opinions diverge on who was being "disrespectful." In short: politics circa 2019.
author: johnmyers

text: “I know what I’m doing,” Feinstein tells the young activists.
author: johnmyers

text: A guy wearing a shirt like that simply has to be talked to when you're a reporter. Follow Christine for the action this weekend at #CAGOP2019 convention. The chair's race is the real news -- and what it will mean for the state party's future.
author: johnmyers

text: President Trump again today took a drive-by swipe at California elections in condemning “any kind of voter fraud” in answer to question about NC case. Absent evidence of widespread or systemic irregularities, it’s a claim that needs to keep being pointed out as baseless.
author: johnmyers

text: My Friday news analysis: Amid chaos, the fate of California’s high-speed rail project becomes a shared burden. @GavinNewsom gives legislators an opening to engage.

text: Just in: Trump administration tells CA it's backing out of $929 million grant to high-speed rail project and "is actively exploring every legal option" to get back the $2.5 billion already given to the effort. This comes one week after Newsom's #CASOTS statement on HSR troubles.

text: Unclear when the legal action will begin. So consider this a "will do" but not "today" action. Newsom says "we're flushing out the details" of what comes next.

text: NEW: "He didn't have to do this. In fact, he can't do this," says @AGBecerra in announcing California lawsuit with @GavinNewsom against Trump administration for declaring national emergency on new U.S.-Mexico border wall construction. Says other states will join the legal action.

text: And the response to the president...

text: Setting aside the inaccuracy that the project is being canceled, not surprising this tweet came. Expect more of this conversation, using California again as a foil, in the coming weeks.
author: johnmyers

text: As he did after the inauguration, ⁦@GavinNewsom⁩ asks supporters via email to chip in $ after he laid out plans in State of the State address.
author: johnmyers

text: My Times analysis of today's #CASOTS as Gov. Newsom sprints out of the long shadow cast by his iconic predecessor.
author: johnmyers

text: Good point. It seems like the narrative this afternoon is, um, careening down the track...
author: johnmyers

text: I suspect that's what they wanted, don't you think? #EyeOfTheBeholder
author: johnmyers

text: We'll be reading tea leaves of @GavinNewsom's #CASOTS on high-speed rail for a long time. For now, seems he wanted to lower the bar while not altogether stop it. Key Q is whether a slowdown gives more time to seek $ to build the whole thing...or signals investors to take a pass.
author: johnmyers

text: And @GavinNewsom's first #CASOTS is over. A lot of news, a lot to chew on. Total speaking time, by my count was 43 minutes and 15 seconds. Bullet train and water tunnels changes, new appointees, talk of healthcare and aging and more. A lot to consider.
author: johnmyers

text: And one more news nugget from #CASOTS. On data privacy, @GavinNewsom says he's "asked my team to develop a proposal for a new Data Dividend for Californians, because we recognize that your data has value and it belongs to you." (Don't know what that means just yet, folks.)
author: johnmyers

text: "It’s time to develop a new modern compact for California’s changing workforce," Newsom says in #CASOTS. "This is... much bigger than Dynamex." (The ellipsis is b/c he keeps adding "respectfully" to his prepared remarks.)
author: johnmyers

text: This is already twice as long as the typical Jerry Brown #CASOTS -- which, of course, was a third as long as those of Schwarzenegger and Davis. Just sayin'.
author: johnmyers

text: Trump shade thrown in #CASOTS by Newsom: "The White House is laser-focused... on destroying the Affordable Care Act." Calls efforts on killing the individual mandate "vandalism."
author: johnmyers

text: More #CASOTS news: @GavinNewsom seems to embrace expansion of rent control in CA. "Get me a good package on rent stability this year and I will sign it" he tells legislators.
author: johnmyers

text: @GavinNewsom gets #CASOTS applause for his approach on housing crisis, less clapping for his approach pushing some cities. Again calls for enviro review to be streamlined for housing efforts.
author: johnmyers

text: @GavinNewsom says in his #CASOTS says he's launching an Alzheimer's task force and taps @mariashriver to lead it. he father, Sargent Shriver, died from the disease... Newsom has long cited him as a hero.
author: johnmyers

text: @GavinNewsom calls for a "Master Plan" for aging in CA. Note: You can read all about the issue in @melmason's fantastic 2018 campaign look at the topic
author: johnmyers

text: If you're keeping track, we haven't had a #CASOTS speech with significant policy pronouncements in a long time. Gov. Brown really didn't see the speech as that kind of event. Newsom is, at least in comparison to Brown, swinging for the fences.
author: johnmyers

text: And another #CASOTS nugget: Newsom taps Sacramento Mayor Darrell Steinberg to lead a new statewide Commission on Homelessness & Supportive Housing.
author: johnmyers

text: More #CASOTS news: @GavinNewsom taps Linda Darling Hammond, a longtime education advocate and researcher, as president of the California State Bd. of Education.
author: johnmyers

text: On energy and PG&E, Newsom's #CASOTS sets 60-days for his strike force to come back with some recommendations. (Me: 60 days as of when?)
author: johnmyers

text: And there's this: a new chair of the CA State Water Resources Control Board. Felicia Marcus to be replaced by Joaquin Esquivel. A #CASOTS with news, unlike most of Brown's.
author: johnmyers

text: And another #CASOTS newsmaking moment: @GavinNewsom says he does not support "the twin tunnels" for CA water project but a smaller project. Lots of Dems didn't applaud. He insists it's an effort to get past "the old binaries."
author: johnmyers

text: "Let’s get something done, once and for all," Newsom says on bullet train. But he insists in #CASOTS that he's not walking away from the project, even as he seems to endorse a radical downsizing.
author: johnmyers

text: This is some big #CASOTS news: @GavinNewsom is recasting bullet train as a more limited project for forseeable future. "The project, as planned, would cost too much and respectfully take too long."
author: johnmyers

text: In his #CASOTS discussion of immigration and decision to cancel the National Guard help to the Trump admin, Newsom makes it clear. "The answer to the White House, with all due respect is no more division, no more xenophobia. No more nativism."
author: johnmyers

text: Newsom notes it's 15 years to the day he helped Phyllis Lyon and Del Martin become groundbreaking same-sex couple to marry in SF -- an effort that ultimately sparked a national change. #CASOTS
author: johnmyers

text: "By every traditional measure, you just heard that, the state of our state is strong." (Yes, like the national speech, a predictable #CASOTS moment.)
author: johnmyers

text: A shout-out to the star of his January inauguration in the #CASOTS speech: "Let me reassure everyone: our son Dutch is not here.  We learned our lesson at the inauguration."
author: johnmyers

text: And here we go: @GavinNewsom's first #CASOTS speech... some tweets to follow in this thread.
author: johnmyers

text: As introductions made for #CASOTS, note that former First Lady Maria Shriver was sitting next to First Partner @JenSiebelNewsom.
author: johnmyers

text: In a brief conversation last week, @GavinNewsom made it clear he doesn't view #CASOTS as an epic address the way most guvs before Brown did. Still, what we're seeing in the early previews is a pretty newsy event. We'll be streaming at
author: johnmyers

text: About an hour away from @GavinNewsom's first #CASOTS speech. Certainly the new governor comes into the annual Sacramento event with some buzz in Monday's decision to pull back the CA Nat'l Guard from border efforts. Doubt that's the only Trump reference we'll hear today.
author: johnmyers

text: News: Very happy to welcome @chabriaa to The Times bureau in Sacramento. Anita will be digging deep into state government, alongside our crack team of @philwillon, @mcgreevy99, @dillonliam, @jazmineulloa, @TarynLuna, @MelodyGutierrez and the indefatigable @LATimesSkelton.
author: johnmyers

text: On Tuesday, he’ll call Trump’s immigration efforts “political theater.” Today, ⁦@GavinNewsom⁩ says he’ll pull the CA National Guard from border with Mexico. Story via ⁦@jazmineulloa⁩ and ⁦@TarynLuna⁩.
author: johnmyers

text: As always, a great honor to hang out with people who are dedicating their lives to public service.
author: johnmyers

text: This morning's column: Is this the year the #CABudget erases the one-day, $1-billion gimmick that has lasted for almost a decade? The governor thinks it should be.
author: johnmyers

text: Paco, you’re too kind. Thanks so much for your support!

text: The McClatchys were once to Sacramento what the Otis/Chandler family was to Los Angeles, the Ochs/Sulzberger family still is to New York. From that storied past to now...where their company cuts staff while giving a $35K/mo. housing stipend to the CEO.

text: We've never really had any kind of sustained momentum on getting this to the next level. So good feedback!

text: Thanks, Connor. Let's keep our fingers crossed!

text: For those folks who have been asking me lately about the politics podcast that I began back in 2006, a thread that tells you where things stand. Simply put, though: this podcast's audience is amazing.

text: Two bills, one fight: California lawmakers again will consider making it easier to prosecute police officers for killing civilians. ⁦@dillonliam⁩ reports...

text: Times analysis: None of the 8 states that Trump admin has cleared to implement a Medicaid work requirement has in place a plan to track whether Medicaid enrollees find jobs or improve their health, two goals often touted by administration health officials.

text: Trump on Newsom and fires today to The Times: “He was very respectful as to my point of view...I think he agrees with me. I respect the fact that he called. The forests are, because of whatever reason, ... extraordinarily flammable, to put it mildly.”

text: 10 of these kids are on the youth  team that I coach. (One of ‘em is my kid, who naturally told Jackson his pop doesn’t like the Tar Heels. That’s my boy!) Great event for our ballers while I was watching SOTU.

text: Final Jeopardy one night in 2052: “It was the year in which the #SOTU included a rousing rendition of ‘Happy Birthday.’”

text: Has there ever been a #SOTU where a president insisted there would never be a socialist United States?

text: Well that didn’t last long.

text: Man, we all needed these moments with young Grace, didn’t we? Her bravery helped cut the tension.

text: The governor’s watching and tweeting...

text: It’s hard to reconcile, in the real world of course, the idea of “our Union is strong” with the palpable tension as Trump rolls through the immigration/wall part of his speech.
author: johnmyers

text: The president has decided to go full tilt on this section of the speech on the border and illegal immigration. Not that it’s surprising, but it does nothing to bring down the national temperature.
author: johnmyers

text: Every president says it. “The state of our Union is strong.” Kind of like picking S, T, R, N, L and E on Wheel of Fortune.

text: This televised event has more awkward cutaway shots than the old “Californians” sketches.

text: New: California elections officials will investigate whether DMV voter registration errors changed the outcome of races, per Monday federal court settlement.

text: "We haven’t been able to land that one big fish yet.” In the tale of two Californias, the struggles never seem to end for Imperial County. Must-read by @sarahparvini and great images via @latfoto.

text: “I want 50 inches on the tick-tock of that ad, a curtain raiser for a year long examination of its impact before its 10th anniversary. A navel gazer with sweep. Don’t forget the killer nut graf.”

text: Fun fact: Sunday marked the 9th anniversary of easily the most unusual California political ad I've ever seen... yes, the #DemonSheep ad from Carly Fiorina's Senate campaign, scolding Tom Campbell while giving us all an unending case of the creeps.

text: Now official: @GavinNewsom's first State of the State will be next Tuesday, Feb. 12. He's sticking with Brown's penchant for mornings (11am), which broke from the traditional late afternoon speeches that used to get carried (or dipped into) by TV newscasts.

text: I’m somewhat amazed that CBS still has its announcers wearing blazers with the eye logo on them. I mean, I admit I loved the legendary Dick Enberg with his 70s NBC blazer. But it’s 2019.

text: Surreal: on UC Berkeley campus, I hear an a cappella group of young men sing “Stacy’s Mom.” And then it hits me: I’m even older than the song’s Ms. Mom.
author: johnmyers

text:
At #CAVotes event during discussion of governor's race, @cmarinucci asks @TimRosales
the big Q: Did John Cox want the Trump endorsement?

"That is such a complex question, on so many levels," Rosales said. 

Good chuckle in the crowd.
author: johnmyers

text: Back on the Berkeley campus today for @BerkeleyIGS quadrennial #CAVotes election post-mortem. Will be moderating afternoon panel on the 2018 congressional battleground races.

text: Weather is to climate as is the Patriots losing to the Titans but making the Super Bowl. One game/storm does not a season/climate make.

text: Flew down to LA tonight with the most beautiful sunset and clear view of the SoCal coast. What a night to see California from above.

text:
Sorry, but “prove it wrong” gives an extraordinary amount of power to non-fact rhetoric. If default position of society is that “everything is true until proven false,” we’ve empowered reckless speech.

Back to voter registration: we need significantly more investigation.
author: johnmyers

text: Context: The report by Texas covered a 22-year period and seems to say that citizenship status couldn’t be confirmed — not that non-citizen status was guaranteed. And yes, another swipe at CA here without additional details.
author: johnmyers

text: This morning’s politics column: a state ombudsman to weigh the release of government documents? One lawmaker offers thought-provoking change to process governed by California Public Records Act.

text: My favorite memory: the lobbyist who, on Valentines Day night session, told me he was thrilled to leave for dinner with his wife b/c he knew he could read my budget debate tweets into the evening...
author: johnmyers

text: February 2009. 10 years of Twitter (for me) next month.
